newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks open firmer after Dow record.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks open firmer after Dow record.

text.p: Australian shares climbed from the opening bell on Monday after the Dow closed at a new record high on Friday, its 31st record close this year following another round of solid corporate earnings reports.
At 10.30 a.m. (0030 GMT), the All Ordinaries index was 8.6 points firmer at 2,363.6.
The December share price index was up seven points at 2,391 and at a 27.4 point premium to the underlying index.
Brokers said benefiting the most from early buying was bellwether stock BHP which was aided by a firmer copper price as well as the Dow's rise on Friday.
"BHP is the standout this morning. There has been plenty of volume early and it is carrying the market at the moment," a dealer at a Brisbane-based brokerage said.
The dealer said resource issues were still favoured over industrials but that most blue chip industrial issues had also opened modestly firmer.
"Interest rates are still a factor affecting industrial issues whereas resources are making up lost ground now that metal prices seem to have stabilised," the dealer said.
Amongst industrial issues, media group News Corp was well supported early after its ADRs rose on Wall Street on Friday.
Market attention was focused on engineering group ANI ahead of its annual meeting in Sydney this morning.

ANI directors are divided over the handling of the company's investment in the troubled Holter Environmental Systems in the early 1990s which has cost ANI more than A$200 million (US$159 million) in losses and writedowns.

Also active early was Foster's Brewing group whose shares opened weaker after it said that its 40 percent owned Canadian brewer, Molson had agreed to discuss a new licensing agreement with U.S. brewer Coors, after an arbitration panel ruling that terminated their previous agreement.
